answers.content_html: The mass number and atomic number of carbon-13 is 13 and 6, while that of carbon-12 is 12 and 6, respectively.
answers.feedback_html: The mass number and atomic number of carbon-13 is 13 and 6, respectively. While, that of carbon-12 is 12 and 6, respectively.

answers.content_html: The mass number and atomic number of carbon-13 is 13 and 12, while that of carbon-12 is 12 and 6, respectively.
answers.feedback_html: The atomic number of carbon-13 is not 12.

answers.content_html: The mass number and atomic number of carbon-13 is 13 and 13, while that of carbon-12 is 12 and 6, respectively.
answers.feedback_html: The mass number and atomic number of carbon-13 are not the same for this isotope of carbon.

answers.content_html: The mass number and atomic number of carbon-13 is 13 and 12, while that of carbon-12 is 12 and 12, respectively.
answers.feedback_html: The atomic number of carbon, and all of its isotopes, is not 12.

answers.content_html: carbonyl
answers.feedback_html: Carbonyl groups contain a carbon atom double-bonded to an oxygen atom.

answers.content_html: hydroxyl
answers.feedback_html: Hydroxyl groups bonds with carbon to form alcohols.

answers.content_html: phosphate
answers.feedback_html: Phosphate groups bond with carbon atoms on molecules such as ATP.

answers.content_html: sodium
answers.feedback_html: Sodium is not a functional group, it is an element. Thus, it does not bond with carbon as a functional group.

answers.content_html: It is the rotational equivalent of a force.
answers.feedback_html: Torque is the turning effectiveness of the applied force.

answers.content_html: It is the force that affects linear motion.
answers.feedback_html: Torque is a rotational quantity. It is the turning effectiveness of the applied force.

answers.content_html: It is the rotational equivalent of acceleration.
answers.feedback_html: Torque is the rotational equivalent of force. Acceleration in rotational mechanics is called angular acceleration.

answers.content_html: It is the acceleration that affects linear motion.
answers.feedback_html: Torque is not acceleration. Torque is the rotational equivalent of force.

answers.feedback_html: The carbon atom has four electrons in its valence shell. Therefore, bonding four more electrons will complete its octet, allowing it to attain a stable configuration. Carbon molecule can thus bond with a maximum of four other atoms.

answers.content_html: By applying the force at different points of the lever arm along the length of the lever or by changing the angle between the lever arm and the applied force.
answers.feedback_html: The torque is defined as the product of the radial vector, the applied force, and the sine of the angle between them. Therefore, different torque can be produced for the same force by applying the force at different points of the lever arm along the length of the lever or by changing the angle between the lever arm and the applied force.

answers.content_html: By applying the force at the same point of the lever arm along the length of the lever or by changing the angle between the lever arm and the applied force.
answers.feedback_html: The torque remains the same when the force is applied at the same point of lever.

answers.content_html: By applying the force at different points of the lever arm along the length of the lever or by maintaining the same angle between the lever arm and the applied force.
answers.feedback_html: The torque does not change when the angle between the radial vector and the applied force is same.

answers.content_html: By applying the force at the same point of the lever arm along the length of the lever or by maintaining the same angle between the lever arm and the applied force.
answers.feedback_html: The torque changes with the change in the length of the radial vector or with the change in the angle between the radial vector and the applied force.

stem_html: How can the same force applied to a lever produce different torques?

answers.content_html: The force should be applied perpendicularly to the lever arm as close as possible from the pivot point.
answers.feedback_html: Remember that torque is directly proportional to the distance from the point of application of force to the pivot.

answers.content_html: The force should be applied perpendicularly to the lever arm as far as possible from the pivot point.
answers.feedback_html: Since the applied force is the same, torque can be increased by increasing the distance from the point of application of the force to the pivot.

answers.content_html: The force should be applied parallel to the lever arm as far as possible from the pivot point.
answers.feedback_html: If force is parallel to the lever arm, then torque will be zero.

answers.content_html: The force should be applied parallel to the lever arm as close as possible from the pivot point.
answers.feedback_html: When the force is parallel to the lever arm, the angle made by the force will be zero and the torque will be zero.

stem_html: How can you maximize the torque applied to a given lever arm without applying more force?
